bibl.title: Deposition of James Gilmooe
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the original.

div1.p: Take notice that on the 18th day of November in the year of our Lord one thousand eight undred and thirty-six, between the hours of eight in the forenoon and five in the afternoon, of that day at the office of David Hough in the City of Saint Louis

depositions will be taken by the undersigned, to be read on the trial of the above entitled case, on behalf of the defendant; and that the taking of said depositions, if not completed on that day, will be continued from day to day at the same place and between the same hours, until completed.
To the above named plaintiff

The plantiff will this today on the attorney of record of plantiff
J. Spalding
15 November

Served this notice by delivering a true copy thereof to H.R. Gamble & Beverly Allen attornies of record of the within named plantiff on the 15th day of November 1836 in the county of St. Louis Edward Gantt the within namd plantiff not found in my county.
James Brotherson Sheriff
By Brotherson D. Sheriff
Service $1.00

State of Missouri
County of Saint Louis

Deposition of a witness produced sworn and examined on this eighteenth day of November eighteen hundred and thirty six between the hours of eight in the forenoon and five in the afternoon of that day before me although a justice of the peace within and for the county aforsaid at my office in the city of Saint Louis in a certain cause now pending in the Saint Louis Circuit Court between Edward Gantt plaintiff and Thomas Baldwin defendant, on behalf of the defendant.

James Gilmore being produced sworn and examined deposith and said that he shows the defendant Thomas Baldwin that he master of the Steam Boat Tempist last fall the said boat then running from Pittsubrgh to Louisville and sometimes to St. Louis, the said boat was in St. Louis two or three times last fall then said boat left St. Louis on or about the 19th December 1835 for Louisville, being the last trip she made that season witness was mate on said Boat from the 8th of September 1835 to the 13th July 1836 and was on her during every trip, and was on board of her during all the time and every time she was at St. Louis. Witness knows of no black or mulatto women taken from St. Louis at any time on said boat except on the last trip two slaves claimed by a person on baord who paid their passage tot hte mouth of the Ohio, where they left the boat with him at Bard's Landing one a mulatto the other black
